content:
When threading was set as default, I complained a lot. That was then. I still don't like threading, but the fix is so easy that I no longer complain. The setting is in the config editor. Here is everything I know on the topic:

This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder in an account and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

More info: To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0=unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: (I creates a crude video that walks through the steps at 

   https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4  that demonstrates the following steps: 
  First, highlight a folder that you have set to unthreaded	   In the Message List view, in the column header, on the far right, open the options button that shows        context menu. :   At the very bottom is the option:   -> "Apply current view to..."   -> "Folder and its children..."   -> Hover over an account   -> In the next menu don't select a folder. Instead select the account name itself.

Repeat the above for each account. Seriously, it is clumsy, but just takes a few minutes.
creator: davidsk

content:
re : so I'm trying to again get rid of Everything Thunderbird put anywhere on my machine so I can start with a clean install.

I mentioned how to do that in previous comment.

Here is info again: Thunderbird will get auto installed in either of these location depending upon whether you are installing a 32bit version or a 64bit version.

  • 64 bit bit version: C:/ Program Files/Mozilla Thunderbird
  • 32 bit bit version: C:/ Program Files (x86)/Mozilla Thunderbird

By default Thunderbird creates a location for all the profile data and it will be here - so I'm presuming you did not put it anywhere else.

  • C://Users/user name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Windows OS also keeps a record of some info in this Appdata/'Local' location but it's not the profile data used by Thunderbird.

  • C://Users/user name/Appdata/Local/Thunderbird

If you want to get rid of 'everything' then you need to Exit Thunderbird first if it is running and then delete all the 'Mozilla Thunderbird' and 'Thunderbird' folders I highlighted above. Then empty the computer 'Recycle Bin'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I've been trying to understand what you've been trying to do.

Did you get a new computer and you wanted to install Thunderbird. You aslo wanted to use a backed up copy of a profile - although at this point it's not clear what you actually backed up and depending upon what you backed up depends upon the process you use to get it all displaying again.

But then you start talking about adding mail accounts which means you did not intend to use an old profile. Or did you want to use a completely clean profile with a brand new imap mail account - but then you wanted to copy a load of pop account emails into the 'Local Folders' mail account ?

What are you trying to achieve?

It now sounds like you are so mixed up, you just want to get rid of everything which is just as drastic.

Thunderbird will get auto installed in either of these location depending upon whether you are installing a 32bit version or a 64bit version.

  • 64 bit bit version: C:/ Program Files/Mozilla Thunderbird
  • 32 bit bit version: C:/ Program Files (x86)/Mozilla Thunderbird

By default Thunderbird creates a location for all the profile data and it will be here:

  • C://Users/user name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Windows OS also keeps a record of some info in this location but it's not the profile data used by Thunderbird.

  • C://Users/user name/Appdata/Local/Thunderbird

If you want to get rid of 'everything' then you need to exit Thunderbird if it is running and then delete all the 'Mozilla Thunderbird' and 'Thunderbird' folders I highlighted above. Then empty the computer 'Recycle Bin'

But before you reinstall, what have you got backed up ? Did you backup this: C://Users/user name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird folder Or backup this: C://Users/user name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/profile name folder

If you backed up the /Roaming/'Thunderbird' folder: If you want the new installation to use that backed up Thunderbird' folder....

Install Thunderbird, let it start but do not add any mail account, just exit Thunderbird. Then access :

  • C://Users/user name/Appdata/Roaming folder - see image below as guide
  • Delete the default 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Paste the backup copy of 'Thunderbird' folder into the 'Roaming' folder, thus replacing the one you deleted.

Start Thunderbird It should start and use all your old settings.

If you have deleted everything to do with Thunderbird and installed Thunderbird afresh, let it create a new default profile and then you created a new mail account that's ok. But I was under the impression you had some email you needed to get access to see.

What exactly have you got backed up - some images would help and I can help you get them into the 'Local Folders' mail account.

content:
Gmail's SMTP server always saves a copy of sent messages in the Sent "folder". This happens on the server side and as far as I'm aware, you cannot control this behaviour. If you are using IMAP access, then all messages that reside in the Sent folder on the server should show up in Thunderbird.

In Thunderbird's menu, go to Help > More Troubleshooting Information > Copy text to clipboard and paste it in your next reply.

content:
I don't think that's going to work because of how calendar data is currently stored in Thunderbird. I tried to reproduce the error you're getting, by importing events from the same ics file, twice, into the same target calendar. The first import is successful because the target calendar is empty. The second import fails with that exact error, and the Error Console gives the exact reason why the import fails as follows:

There has been an error reading data for calendar: Home. However, this error is believed to be minor, so the program will attempt to continue. Error code: DUPLICATE_ID. Description: ID already exists for addItem

The problem is the IDs of the events you're importing from the file are already in use by existing events in the target calendar. This ID is a unique identifier for each event, and therefore cannot be shared between events in the same database. In other words, duplicates of the ID are not allowed into the database. This therefore means you cannot simply import the same events on top of each other and overwrite the existing ones, thus eliminating duplicates and keeping only one entry of each event. Not in the current version of Thunderbird that I know of anyway. Thunderbird now uses SQlite as its database for calendar data storage. Perhaps there is an add-on for doing that. You could also file a feature request (enhancement request) to skip duplicate items here bugzilla.mozilla.org if one hasn't already been filed.

You may want to use an external tool to merge the ics files from the two calendars into one ics file, then import that into a new blank calendar. I can't offer any recommendations for such a tool as I've simply not had to do this before. Google Calendar apparently automatically merges duplicates. You could use that and then export the resultant calendar.

content:
Dear Toad-Hall

Thank you for your detailed reply. As you think, the reason may be that we are using IMAP and the recycle bin was not synchronized with the server.

The error message indicated that the deleted email could not be moved. So, I tried to move them to a different folder by moving them instead of deleting them, and that stopped the problem.

After further investigation, we confirmed that the Trash was set to not synchronize, so we modified it to synchronize.

I think this probably improved the situation, so I will give it a while.

Thank you very much for all your advice.

content:
Are you using an imap mail account? I'm assuming you use an Imap account, so tell me if it's a pop account.

Do you have any Anti-Virus which is scanning incoming mail?

Do you see any errors in Error Console? Tools > Developer Tools > Error Console

Filter - You selected 'Delete a Message' Do these 'deleted' emails normally get moved to 'Trash' folder when that filter is working?

I'm wondering if filter cannot move item to imap Trash folder because the Trash has not been synchronised with server, so filter gets auto disabled. Sounds crazy but I have heard of this somewhere - I'll have to do a bit of digging to locate it.

In the meantime:

  • In Folder Pane, right click on 'Trash' and select 'Properties'
  • Make sure this checkbox is selected - 'When getting new messages for this account, always check this folder'
  • click on 'OK'

Please confirm the above is selected.

If you had to make that change, then wait a while to see if changing those settings means the filter does not get disabled. Report on results.

If the Trash Properties already had that checkbox selected OR if changing the setting had no effect and filter got disabled again try this:

Regarding the Filter - Action is 'Delete a Message' TEST: change this to 'Move to folder' and select 'Trash on imap account' Save and make sure the Filter is enabled.

Report on whether this workaround functions better.

content:
re :The message filter has been turning off

Do you mean specific message filters seem to stop working or all of them? You say 'turning off' which means 'disabling'. When you click on 'Message Filters' You should see a list of filters you created ? Do you mean you can see the list but all the checkboxes have been unchecked so disabling all the Message Filters ? That would be odd.

OR do you mean you have emails that should get filtered but they are not being auto filtered? Do those emails get incorrectly filtered to another folder or are they still in the Inbox ? Is this a particular filter which is not always filtering? If yes, post an image of that filter.

Have you checked the Filter Log to see what is going on ?

In 'Message Filters' Click on 'Filter Log' button Is the Filter Log enabled ? If no then click on the checkbox 'Enable the Filter Log' Then close the window. Next time a filter fails then you may find out what the filters were doing via this log.

content:
comcast - that's xfinity and you are using Pop. This means you would only be able to download emails that have been put into the server Inbox folder.

If the server is putting any emails you send to yourself and Cc = your email address into 'Spam' folder then you would not be aware of anything in thunderbird because the POP account has no knowledge of the server Spam folder.

I believe xfinity also empty spam folder every 7 days. https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/set-email-deletion-settings

Logon to webmail account and check out what is currently in the server Spam folder and what is listed as spam email addresses - maybe your email address has got into that list. Maybe you need to set your email address as a whitelist address.

Someone else had a similar issue, but they were accessing emails via laptop and phone and discovered it was their phone messing things up. https://forums.xfinity.com/conversations/email/email-from-myself-to-myself-going-to-spam-on-my-laptop/642aed324d04032f94614581
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : In the cc: field I used the same address I sent the message to GMAIL from, the one already synced with Thunderbird.

I know that because you have already told the forum.

What I do not know is whether the FROM which you used was another gmail address thus using the gmail smtp server and if it wasn't then what smtp server did you use to send? Hence the additional questions.

As I mentioned there are some servers that do not allow Cc to same address as used for sending, but at this point no one can check it out because you've not told us what smtp server was used.

I also asked: does the copied 'Sent' message in 'Sent' folder correctly display the Cc? But you have not told us the answer. That would confirm the message was sent correctly by Thunderbird to the smtp server. In other words, if message was sent correctly to server then the reason the Cc was not actioned upon is not Thunderbird, it's the server - but then what is the smtp server?

Sometimes it can be calculated what the smtp server is by looking at whatever is after the @ in the FRom email address or what is the 'server name' of the outgoing server smtp used for that From email address. Hence the request for additional info which you have not as yet supplied.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : However, I sent an email with attachment to my GMAIL address, which is not synced with Thunderbird,

I presume you sent the email using Thunderbird. You sent TO a gmail email address, but that gmail account is not a mail account in Thunderbird. Did the email explicitly show your email address in a Cc field ? Do you see a copy of that sent email in the 'Sent' folder and does it have your email address in the Cc field? But what account sent the email ? What comes after the @ in your email address? Is it another gmail address ? Did you put the same email address which you used to send an email - it was in the FROM field - you put same email address into the Cc field ?

Some mail services will suppress CC to oneself. gmail is one of those servers. If you are sending using a gmail account then gmail will not honour the Cc to yourself. In gmail webmail account try this to see if it works. Settings->Filters (in the Gmail web interface), make a filter for all message FROM you, and use the "never send to spam" option. That should force a copy to your Inbox.
